titleStmt.title: Coomleagh East

editor.orgName: Maynooth University, Department of Early Irish
Maynooth University, Department of Early Irish

respStmt.name: Gary Dempsey
respStmt.resp: Photogrammetry used to create 3d model of stone , processed using Agisoft Metashape.

msItem.textLang: Primitive Irish written in ogham script

supportDesc.support:
National Monuments Service SMR ID: CO106-064---- Stone pillar (one of stone pair/alignment)
2.00 1.10 0.60
Macalister (1945, 59) recorded an ogham inscription on the upright stone of a pair of standing stones (CO106-035----, the second lies prostrate 1.m to E). He also noted that there was a row of three stones here in 1879, reduced to two by 1907 (Macalister 1907, 31-7). The ogham stone was probably part of a prehistoric stone alignment and the inscription added at a later date to emphasise a land ownership or territorial claim. It is in an area with a concentration of such prehistoric monuments. The long axis of the stone is NE/SW (F. Moore field notes) which would support the suggestion that it is prehistoric in origin (Archaeological Survey of Ireland (ASI field report), SMR ID: CO106-064----).
supportDesc.condition: The inscription was badly damaged some time after 1845. When examined by Fionnbarr Moore in the early 1980s only traces of the final four letters of the inscription could be discerned and while these were quite vague they were undoubtedly ogham scores, knife cut in the style of many Cork oghams (Archaeological Survey of Ireland, SMR ID: CO106-064----).

layoutDesc.layout: Macalister (1945, 60) noted that the inscription is found on the lower half of the stone on the right angle of the eastern face, and runs up from near the ground to a height of 1.1m.

handDesc.handNote: The ogham scores have been knife-cut, which is consistent with many Cork ogham inscriptions. The consonant scores are small, measuring from 2 to 4 centimeters in length.

origin.origPlace: Coomleagh East (An Com Liath Thoir), Co. Cork 51.72827, -9.30337

provenance.p: The ogham inscription was first discovered in 1845 by Roger Downing of Bantry. It was afterwards seen and copied by Windele. Brash, visiting the stone later, found that only a week previously a man had flaked off most of the inscribed angle with the back of an axe. The two copies made before this act are almost identical so far as the number of the scores goes, but otherwise they cannot be reconciled; nor can any sense be extracted from either of them (Macalister 1945, 59).

history.provenance: In situ in pasture, on a gentle south facing slope on the north side of the valley of the Mealagh River (ASI field report). Visited and 3d recorded for the OG(H)AM project in September 2022.

encodingDesc.p: Encoded following the latest EpiDoc guidelines

listChange.change: Jef Bucas autogenerated EpiDoc output from spreadsheet.
Patricia O Connor added and encoded further data, including measurements as well as information about the condition and execution of the inscription and updated the edition.
Patricia O Connor updated information on the condition, layout, and execution of the inscription; the placename in Irish; as well as the provenance of the ogham stone.

Nora White added 3d recording information (who, when (provenance observed), how and where accessible). Also, updated digital edition by adding lemmas to words (awaiting reconstructed nom forms from David) and additional references.
Patricia O Connor converted Macalister's measurements and encoded date and personal name information.

media.desc: 3d model by Gary Dempsey on SketchFab
